dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUN TITLES over a series of EXTREME CLOSE-UPS: A pair of human hands working delicately on tiny cogs and machinery. A human eye grotesquely expanded though a magnifying glas A tiny screwdriver tightening a tiny screw. Intricate internal mechanisms of silver, gold and jewels. INTERCUT with shots of beautiful and intricate automata; A Monkey-Musician in blue and gold livery holding a violi A Harlequin holding the hand of a coy Columbine. A silver-faced clown perched on a trapeze. The TITLES end. WIDEN to reveal the workshop of PHILLIP LEMARCHAND lit by candlelight. The automata stand on wood shelves which line the room along with plans and drawings At the workbench, Phillip - handsome, 30, obsessed by his craft - is hunched over his work, keeping us from seeing Super-imposed: THE OUTSKIRTS OF PARIS 1784 There’s a strange atmosphere. Perhaps it’s the CRAZY SHAD thrown by the flickering candles. Perhaps it’s the sound the WIND in the midnight darkness outside. Perhaps it’s t amplified HEARTBEAT of Phillip. Something gives an edge t scene. We’re waiting for something to happen. With a cry of triumph as something clicks into place, Phi sits back on his chair, his latest creation in his palm. We recognise the object of black wood and filigreed gold LAMENT CONFIGURATION, a hell-summoning Box from HELLRAISE The workroom door opens and Phillip’s wife GENEVIEVE ente Mid-20’s and beautiful, she is in her nightdress.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Is it done?

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Done!

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEV
dialogues.text: (yawning) Is it wonderful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Are you brilliant?

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: (returning the smile) The finest toymaker in France! They both laugh affectionately. Beneath their words and t smiles, though, is an undercurrent of .. what? Anxiety? Uncertainty? Perhaps they both sense Phillip is involved something that he doesn’t quite understand.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: What does it do? Proudly, Lemarchand manipulates the Box through various positions until, at a certain point, the mechanisms withi seem to take over and it moves itself into the final swas like configuration familiar from the previous films ... and remains sitting on Lemarchand’s hand. No chains, hooks, no blue lights, no screams of pain or pleasure. The interested smile on Genevieve’s face falters.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Oh. (beat) It doesn’t actually do anything, then?

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: (stung into cold defensiveness) It all but defies the laws of physical geometry! It’s my masterpiece! You simply couldn’t understand...

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: I meant no offense, Phillip. I’m sure it’s terribly intri It’s just... dull. I prefer your acrobats and lovers. Laughing disarmingly, she crosses to the shelves and acti some of the older automata. The monkey musician begins to at his fiddle. Harlequin kisses Columbine, who hides her behind a fan. The Clown swings over and around his trapez Lemarchand, far from placated, is standing and fastening cloak around himself.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: I was working to a commission. To very specific requests. Duke has what he wanted. Genevieve registers the cloak as Lemarchand heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s midnight! Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: The Chateau Du Reve to deliver the box.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Now!? Why?

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Because my work might be appreciated there. And it is the appointed hour. Opening the door, Box in hand, he sweeps from the room. Genevieve watches the door close behind him.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: The appointed hour - Midnight! Aristocrats... (cont.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magnificent mansion stands in its own grounds. Below it lawns is a front gate. A SHADOWY FIGURE hovers at the gat beggar or derelict of some kind. The camera moves to show Lemarchand at the impressive front door of the Chateau.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: (off) (cont.) ... Such strange people. The door is opened by JACQUES, a 19 year-old servant-cum- apprentice to the Chateau’s owner - who stands behind him powdered and periwigged DUC DE L’ISLE. De L’Isle’s age is hard to determine beneath the layers o white powder that cover his face but the red and rheumy e and spidery limbs suggest he is at least in his late 50'’ From somewhere in the house, a clock tolls midnight. DE’L’ ISLE Lemarchand. As precise as your pieces, as timely as your Enter, enter. Lemarchand steps over the threshold...

dialogues.text: into the hall - candle-lit, its outer reaches lost in shadow. There’s an impression of decay beneath the finery bright light would probably show peeling paint and cobweb  De L’Isle’s eyes glitter as he looks at the Box in Lemarchand’s hand. Jacques closes the door and looks at Lemarchand and De L’ as they walk away. There is a look in his eyes - covetous ambitious, and secretive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room lit by many candles, providing a rich atmosphere o contrasting orange light and flickering black shadows. EIGHT CARDPLAYERS - male, four finely-attired, the other in military uniform - sit at a large table. A game in pro halts as the players look up as De L’Isle and Lemarchand enter. DE L’ISLE A moment, gentlemen, forgive me. Madame? A stunningly beautiful woman, emerging from the shadows a room’s end, moves to De L’Isle and Lemarchand. This is the PRINCESS ANGELIQUE. Dark, mysterious, exquisi DE L’ISLE Phillip Lemarchand - The Princess Angelique. Angelique extends her hand. Lemarchand - visibly struck b beauty - bends to kiss it. As he straightens, he finds hi the subject of a penetrating stare and a ravishing smile.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Your fame precedes you, toymaker DE L’ISLE The Princess is your true patron, Lemarchand. The Box was conception, your employment her idea. Lemarchand places the Box in the hands of Angelique.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Though the box is unworthy of your beauty, Princess, I pr its amusements be worthy of your attention.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: I thank you, sir. And I pray your workmanship is as elega your tongue. Phillip glows in the warmth of her smile and her words. face falls, however, as she instantly turns to De L’Isle.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: (flatly, unsmiling) Pay him. She turns without another word and moves back into the ro leaving De L’Isle amused at Phillip’s obvious disappointm DE L’ISLE Never mistake your superior’s politeness for affection, toymaker. And never forget your place. The sound of a firmly closing door bridge the CUT TO

dialogues.text: And what would be the challenge here, De L’Isle? To name frippery? dialogues.speaker: CORBUSIER
dialogues.text: (looking her up and down) A pretty name, Madame. Are the stakes you would offer as attractive? The others giggle at the lascivious implication in his wo Angelique silences them with a freezing glance and then - playing them perfectly - allows a coy smile to blossom on face. She holds the Box up again.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: The Box looks solid, Gentlemen, but in skilful hands may unlocked and maneuvered. Pass it among yourselves. For ev successful stripping of its secrets... I shall respond in kind. To appreciative murmurs from the players, Angelique raise Box to her lips and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Now it is complete. Will you play, Sir? She proffers it to Corbusier, who takes it eagerly and be to manipulate it, searching for its secrets. dialogues.speaker: CORBUSIER
dialogues.text: What? The players all stare in fascination at the moving Box.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: As I say. Always more secrets. But a wager is a wager... She begins to loose the catches of her corset. De L’Isle moves to stand with Jacque. INTERCUT the Box’s movements with the loosening of the co The Box clicks into a penultimate position and BLUE LIGHT glows bright from within it and through the seams at its sides. Lemarchand is shocked. The Box has secrets its maker didn suspect. Before he can see more, the drapes suddenly FALL against the window - as if something knows he’s watching. The players don’t notice; breath held, their eyes are on Angelique as she opens her corset to reveal herself... Her torso transforms - suddenly it is covered in a score SCREAMING MOUTHS and DEMONIC EYES that stare balefully ou into the room. Her FLESH RIPPLES in constant motion as if of impossible life! dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: The first of many, Sir. I found a rare talent in Lemarcha De L’Isle’s face becomes cold and imperious. DE L’ISLE Go to my room, Madam, and wait for me. dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a human arm, as a scalpel slices it and a pair o hands peel the flesh back, revealing the musculature bene WIDEN TO REVEAL a big room, its floor sawdust-covered and blood-soaked, and full of tables on each of which are SHE COVERED CORPSES. At one table, sleeves rolled up and working hard at his dissection, is AUGUSTE DE MARAIS, a 30 year old professor science and philosophy. He has no students with him but o his friend Lemarchand. Auguste is smiling broadly, having heard Lemarchand’s story. (Auguste continues his efficient preparation of the corps throughout their conversation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pity Mme. De Beaumont is dead these four years. You cou have sold her your story and given her another success to match her “Beauty and the beast”.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: It is no story, Auguste! I saw what I saw, heard what I h The Box opens the doors of Hell!

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTE
dialogues.text: This is the eighteenth century, not the dark ages. The wo is ruled by Reason. We’ve even got rid of God. And if the no Heaven then it follows, reasonably, that there is no H

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: I was at its very window last night! Auguste looks at his friend, hears the conviction in his voice.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTE
dialogues.text: Very well. Suppose for the sake of argument that what you happened, happened. A Box that opens the doors of Hell mu able to close them.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Scant comfort, Auguste. The Box belongs to people with li interest in closing such doors.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTE
dialogues.text: Then the solution lies - literally - in your hands. You designed a machine that you fear can bring forth demons.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTE
dialogues.text: Then design a machine that can destroy them. As Auguste bends down to the difficult (and two-handed) t of pulling the corpse’s rib-cage open, Lemarchand stares his friend, his eyes suddenly excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The workbench is littered with papers filled with designs drawings. They reveal a progression from the design of th lament Configuration towards something else. Lemarchand works feverishly on a design which completes t process. The six faces of the Box are drawn at the edges the paper. Lines from points on the faces meet in the cen of the paper to form a shape. From the Box itself has com own opposite. The new shape, while arising from the Box anti-thetical to it; a cat’s-cradle of interconnecting an curving lines, rather than a solid and angular mass. Lemarchand runs his fingers over the shape in the centre the paper, his eyes burning with the beginning of understanding.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: (off) Phillip? A visitor. Lemarchand looks up from his desk to the door. Genevieve there and, beside her, Angelique - at the sight of whom Lemarchand barely manages to conceal his gasp.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Princess.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Toymaker . A beat. Angelique looks meaningfully to her side, indicat Genevieve’s presence.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Thank you, Genevieve. More eye-language as Genevieve leaves - hers showing ange being asked to leave, his trying to imply apology. dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Forgive this unannounced visit

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: An honour. A pleasure. A... A... Lemarchand is fumbling. He’s afraid. What does this visit mean? Though it’s daytime and Angelique is both polite an beautiful, his memory of last night is strong. Angelique further in, an amused smile on her lips.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Do I make you nervous? How delightful.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: You took me by surprise. I was working.

dialogues.text: Business? Were you dissatisfied with the piece I made?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: I was delighted. Transformed. I want more, Phillip. And s my masters. (off his look) Men and women of power. Ready reward genius. Gold. Fame. The smiles of fair women...

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: I have a wife.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Oh. Is that who that was? Well. Whatever. My point is thi can offer you a world which will appreciate a man of your skills.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: The Duke is rich, I know, but his influence is not so gre

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: De L’Isle? (laughs) Forget him. An initial contact, that’ all. When I say “Power”, I mean real power. And when I sa “Reward”, I mean real rewards.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Great rewards are usually accompanied by great risks.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Your caution is justified. You will hear strange stories see strange sights. But you are not in danger. You are my friend. She raises her hand to stroke delicately at his face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends can share things, Phillip. Secret things. Things wives needn’t know. Their eyes lock. He leans forward, as if to claim a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: We shall make great things and see great wonders, you and (a beat) Tonight. The Chateau. A masked ball. Come. Meet patrons. Claim your future. dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTE
dialogues.text: Good. (off Phillip’s surprised look) The good man must kn his enemy. Must look it in the face and understand it. Auguste stands up and heads for the door

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auguste walks through a deserted wood. The sunlight has strange quality - pregnant with darkness, ready for twili A large BLACK BIRD flies and lands on a high branch. It s to be staring at August... Auguste turns into a clearing and suddenly there is a WHO of sound and a FLURRY of movement! Auguste starts back with a gasp. The movement resolves in ACROBAT tumbling through the air in a cartwheel dive and landing upright, grinning madly, a foot in front of Augus LAUGHTER and APPLAUSE draw Auguste’s eyes forward: Stretched between two trees is a painted-sheet backdrop. Before it, a TROUPE OF CLOWNS, the traditional figures of century Commedia Dell’Arte: HARELQUIN, COLUMBINE, PIERROT PULCINELLA, and THE SURGEON, with four ACROBATS. Their costumes are even more exaggerated and bizarre than norma they all have strange half-smiles, as if they posess a se knowledge. Or are close to the borders of sanity. dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTE

dialogues.text: Philosophy! A fine trade, and never to be confused with training of frogs, which is - I speak from experience - a overrated profession.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTE
dialogues.text: With respect, I have no time to discuss the relative virt of men’s careers. To where do you wish to be directed?

dialogues.speaker: SURGEON
dialogues.text: To the Chateau Du Reve, sir. We are to perform at a great masked ball.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTE
dialogues.text: You are but a mile away. Clear the wood and you shall see

dialogues.speaker: SURGEON
dialogues.text: (speaking with gratitude) Your kindness must be rewarded, sir. Players! Prepare! The Clowns draw two TRUMPETS and a BASS DRUM from a sack

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTE
dialogues.text: I thank you. But you must excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: SURGEON
dialogues.text: And leave you unsatisfied, sir? An unsatisfied audience i saddest thing in the world, save a one-legged fish in a b of pork.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUSTE
dialogues.text: I assure you. There is no need.

dialogues.speaker: SURGEON
dialogues.text: But I insist. Suddenly, from his coat, the Surgeon produces two gleamin BUTCHER’S KNIVES which he holds upright, one in each hand The Acrobat near Auguste does a back-flip and ends up beh the startled Philosopher, blocking his path.

dialogues.speaker: SURGEON
dialogues.text: A brief diversion in your busy day, sir. An entertainment entitled YOUR LAST SIGHT ON EARTH, and guaranteed to plea (to troupe) Music! Pierrot and Pulcinella blow trumpets. An Acrobat pounds t drum. The music is piercing and discordant. Another Acrobat somersaults swiftly to Auguste and, held by an Acrobat on each side, he is carried to the backdrop where Harlequin and Columbine are in a pantomime argument Harlequin, with angry looks and pointing fingers, is accu Columbine, with fervent eyes and imploring hands, is deny  The acrobats bring Auguste on “stage”. Yes, this is her secret lover

The Black Bird keeps watching as the show continues. Harlequin confers silently with the Surgeon, now on stage Surgeon, sympathetic, offers one of his knives. Harlequin looks at the knife, at Auguste, shakes his head. The Surg produces a duelling pistol from his pocket. Harlequin sha his head. The Surgeon tries again and produces a lobster some cheese. LEMARCHAND’S COTTAGE NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BLACKNESS resolves into a NIGHT SKY above the cottage INT. LEMARCHAND’S BEDROOM NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemarchand, eyes open, is lying with his arm around Gene who is asleep. A beat, and he takes his arm away, slips quietly from the bed, and begins dressing in the semi- darkness. He hasn’t got far before Genevieve sits up in bed.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to wake you. I...

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) You’re as automatic as one of your toys! She turns your k and you perform!

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: You’re being ridiculous. You refuse to see what this coul mean for us.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: I know what she means for us!

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: You’d have me turn my back on fortune because of some pet female jealousy!

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: It isn’t that! It isn’t just that. It’s that place. Those people.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: “Those people” are going to give me...

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: A son?! Because that’s what I’m going to give you, Philli son. A beat. He stares at her, anger replaced by incredulous happiness. He clambers on the bed to fling his arms round wife, who is somewhere between laughter and tears at the strength of his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: This is wonderful. Are you sure? (off her happy nod) All more reason I must go. He kisses her forehead and leaves the bed again.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: No! You belong here! With me. With us.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: We belong together. But not here. My son will be born ina palace! Built by the fortune I go to claim tonight. He flings the bedroom door open and is gone. Genevieve s at the closed door, distraught.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: No. No!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CHATEAU DE REVE NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Chateau sits atop its hilled gardens, framed by a nig sky where heavy grey clouds gather oppressively, presagin thunder. In the distance, still peddling his wares, the Derelict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemarchand enters the Ballroom, a space of smoke and laug and the chink of wine-glasses. MUSICIANS play. Jacques se drinks. There are sixteen guests, eight men, eight women. are elaborately MASKED but the eight men seem familiar - are the GAMBLERS. Lemarchand, startled by the grotesque masks and drunken laughter, moves through the ballroom, looking for Angeliq He sees movement through a connecting door and walks through...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .. into a very dimly-lit room with very little furniture. a small table is the Box, a few candles burning around it circular rug sits in the centre of the floor Angelique’s there, holding a thin wand connected to a bir mask in front of her face. Her mask and costume are black featured, reminding us of the bird that watched Auguste d Lemarchand bows courteously. She places her hand on his a and moves in very close to him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: I knew you’d come. You’re a brave man, Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Not so brave. It would be a foolish man who ignored the promise of success.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Then the world is full of fools.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Or empty of promise.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: No. The promise is everywhere. Success is limited only b desire. The wise man sees that. The brave man acts on it.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Then so far I may have been wise. But not yet brave. Angelique tilts her beautiful head and pulls aside the ma

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Be brave... She’s irresistible. Their mouths meet in a deep slow kiss Suddenly, THREE GUESTS in a drunken gavotte spill in from ballroom, nearly colliding into them. One of them spies Angelique’s face. We recognise the voice behind the mask

dialogues.speaker: CORBUSIER
dialogues.text: Ah! Our Lady of the Labyrinth! Swept into formation, she’s spun out of the room. Lemarch dizzy from the kiss, is startled by a VOICE from the shad DE L’ISLE (off) What did she taste of, toymaker? De L’Isle walks forward, turning up the wick on an oil-la carries to show himself more clearly. Unlike his guests, unmasked - though his face is twisted in suppressed rage.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: My apologies, you excellency. I thought we were alone. DE L’ISLE Tasted sweet, didn’t she? Vanilla. To hide the stench of death. Come here. Waving the oil-lamp, he beckons Lemarchand to the middle the room. He angles the light down toward the floor... and yanks away the circular rug, revealing a large painte pattern on the wooden slates - a five-pointed star within circle. A Pentagram. DE L’ISLE That’s what your Box is designed to replace. That and a f words of Old Latin. Such outmoded medieval methods.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Methods of what? DE L’ISLE (sneers) You really don’t know what you’ve gotten yourself into, d you? (a beat) Methods of summoning creatures from Hell. He lifts the light to their faces - his amused, Lemarcha appalled. INT. LEMARCHAND’S WORKROOM NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera roams, moving to the workbench - where we see the cat’s-cradle design - and round to reveal Genevieve. she scan’s the room, looking at Phillip’s designs and sketches, she is putting on a cloak. Her face is set ina determined mask. She’s going to fetch her husband back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lamp is on the floor. De L’Isle has picked up the Box is bouncing it in his hand as he walks towards Lemarchand backs away, both describing a circle around the Pentagram DE L’ISLE I introduced her to your skill. Little did I know that yo science was to replace my magic.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: You misunderstand. The Princess has offered me more work, that’s all. DE L’ISLE There’d be no end of work, toymaker, no end of work. They full of ideas. Always have been. But they needed a human genius to make their ideas manifest. How they must have l for History to deliver them one such as you. Face creased with anger, he hurls the Box at Lemarchand’s face. Lemarchand blocks it, catches it, and looks up to s that De L’Isle has drawn a long and lethal dagger from hi belt. DE L’ISLE But I’m not ready to retire. (gestures to the Pentagram) That’s where I summoned her. That’s where I’11 send her back... Once I’ve killed you! He lunges viciously. Lemarchand throws himself back, avoi the knife but losing his footing and falling to the floor De L’Isle move sin, towering menacingly above Lemarchand. and is suddenly seized from behind by Angelique, whose face is contorted in cold fury. She grasps the knife hand SNAPS HIS WRIST easily! De L’Isle cries out in pain and cringes visibly, backing as Angelique advances on him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: A true magician never forgets the rules. A summoned demo yours to command forever - unless you stand in hell’s way Hell needs this man. And I no longer need you... She grasps De L’Isle by the throat and hoists him impossi high with one hand... and effortlessly flings him more than thirty feet to SMAS through a glass window at the far end of the room! Almost as an afterthought, she clicks her fingers... and magically, the huge curtains gathered up to each side of the window unfurl and close over the shattered glass. Lemarchand rises to his feet as she moves toward him.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Dancing with another. Do you toy with my jealousy, Philli (laughs) Lemarchand isn’t laughing. He backs away from her... and the painted pattern of the Pentagram. Angelique freezes on the edge of the pattern. It’s clear can’t - or won’t - enter. She smiles beguilingly and hold arms out to Lemarchand.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: I confess, sir, your kiss has confirmed the promise of yo eyes. I burn for you, my love. Come to me.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: (flat and final) I think not, Madame. Instantly, the siren-side of Angelique disappears. She dr her arms and her smile and is all business.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Well. To commerce. You have a talent. I have a fortune. S your terms.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: I think not, Madame. Angelique’s face clouds with cold fury.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Think again, Sir. Lemarchand’s silence is eloquent

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Neither pleasure nor fortune persuades you? Then we must something else.  She clicks her fingers as she did before. Instantly, the closed curtains fly open with a flourish l the curtains of a theatre... and they don’t give on to a shattered window but to an IMPOSSIBLY LONG CORRIDOR disappearing into a dark distanc And from it into the room comes the Troupe of Clowns. Two Acrobats blow discordant trumpets and two more beat bass drums. Lemarchand stares in shock and fear as the Clowns produce their knives and smile their maniac smiles. Suddenly, one of the Acrobats frees his Bass Drum and rol swiftly at Lemarchand. It hits his feet, falls to its sid ... and reveals that it’s made of HUMAN SKIN - and, in th middle, still hideously recognisable, are the STRETCHED A

dialogues.speaker: TORTURED FEATURES OF AUGUSTE
dialogues.text: Lemarchand staggers back - and out of the Pentagram! Angelique steps in front of him, her face creased in a sadistic grin, as the Clowns spread out into the room beh her. Lemarchand’s eyes dart everywhere - judging distances.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: And what do you think now, sir?

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: I thank God my poor dead friend guided my hand to better this morning!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: What do you mean? As he answers, Angelique’s face clouds in fury and suspic

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: I mean that everything made may be unmade. That everythin open may be closed. And suddenly he makes his break, running madly for the do the Ballroom before any of the Clowns can reach him. But, to the sound of Angelique’s demonic LAUGHTER, the do opens from the far side and the eight masked gamblers rus Lemarchand stops and stares at the gamblers... as they rip the masks from their faces, revealing the GROTESQUE PALLOR and HIDEOUS SCARS of their dead faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AS promised, gentlemen. A new game! The faces of the ZOMBIE GAMBLERS break into cruel and hun grins as they advance toward Lemarchand.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CHATEAU DU REVE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Genevieve, moving through the gardens in the moonlit dark is pressing her way through a thicket. We are CLOSE on her face... on her hands... on her foot.. as a HAND suddenly shoots from the undergrowth and grabs her ankle! Genevieve SCREAMS and jerks herself free, running furious the path towards the front door. Behind her, dragging himself from the undergrowth, we see L’Isle, badly cut and bruised. At the front door, Genevieve pounds on it and gets no response. Trying the handle, she finds it’s unlocked and herself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Genevieve pauses in the unlit hallway, unsure of where to She sees a faint light coming from a room in the distance

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Genevieve creeps into the room, still lit by the oil-lamp apparently empty except for a bundle of rags on the floor which suddenly murmurs her name.

dialogues.speaker: TORTURED VOICE
dialogues.text: Genevieve... With a cry, Genevieve moves nearer to the shape on the fl It is Lemarchand, horribly wounded and very close to deat

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: No! No! Phillip! Genevieve falls to her knees, cradling her poor husband’s in her arms. Panic crosses what’s left of Lemarchand’s fa He presses the Box into her hands.

dialogues.speaker: LEMARCHAND
dialogues.text: Genevieve! Get out! Save yourself! Save the child...

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: (off)  Child? Suddenly, Angelique and the Gamblers are in the room! Del and Corbusier grab Genevieve and drag her to her feet. Despair crosses Lemarchand’s face and he finally dies.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Phillip!! (sobs) Angelique moves to Genevieve, sadistic triumph on her fac

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: What kind of monster are you?!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: The careful kind. Phillip Lemarchand can have no child. H bloodline must die with him lest his genius be reborn and turned against us.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: No! You can’t!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Believe me, I can. Fingers bent into claws, she moves toward Genevieve... Suddenly De L’Isle hurtles into frame, seizing Angelique! With the advantage of surprise and momentum, he propels b himself and the Princess into the Pentagram where, before of the Gamblers can react, he shouts out a Latin revocati DE L’ISLE Exeunt Omnia Malefica! All the Gamblers devolve instantly into HUMAN-SHAPED TOWE WORMS, each a mass of pink and brown writhing shapes whic drop to the floor, where their wrigglings are overtaken b collective transformation into LUMPS OF PRIMAL OOZE... which, in turn, become PILES OF DRY DUST which, seized by supernatural wind, are swept away into nothingness. Simultaneously, Angelique SCREAMS... and EXPANDS, her bod MORPHING impossibly into a huge mass of DEMONIC EYES and SCREAMING DEMONIC MOUTHS - an even more nightmarish versi the revelation she gave the gamblers the previous night! There is a BLINDING FLASH OF LIGHT... And suddenly, Genevieve is completely alone in the room. Still holding her husband’s Box and completely freaked ou all she has seen, she turns and flees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Genevieve turns into the street, she is startled by th Derelict. He goes into his usual rap.

dialogues.speaker: DERELICT
dialogues.text: Wonders, Madam? Spices of the orient? Perfumes from far Cathay? Genevieve looks at him. She looks at the Box in her hand. looks at the Chateau and its memories of evil. She hands Box to the startled and delighted Derelict and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF CLOSE-UPS: A hand lights many candles. The Pent is sprinkled with salt. An ancient-looking book is opened page of Latin manuscript. Latin words are intoned monosyllabically. And there is a burst of light... and Angelique is back within the Pentagram. She looks startled, glancing round the room, confused. Jacques, the apprentice, is standing outside the pentagra is he who has staged the ritual.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: Welcome, Princess.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: You? You summoned me?

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: And he who summons the magic, commands the magic. You bel to me. Forever. Angelique’s face falls. Have her great ambitions come to

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: And I will never make De L’Isle’s mistake, Princess. Coun that. He begins to laugh as he draws her from the Pentagram and strokes her face in proprietory lust.

Super-imposed: THE CLIPPER “LIBERTE”, EN ROUTE TO NEW YOR  INT. “LIBERTE”, SMALL CABIN DAY The very pregnant Genevieve sit sin her tiny cabin. She i reading intently in a small leather-bound volume. dialogues.text: You’re the one, Johnny. You’re the one they’ve been waiti for... - Elevator doors clanging together and a VOID behind them The images flick back and forth, faster and faster, achie a nightmare crescendo, until suddenly the BLACKNESS is ba and we hear a MALE VOICE SCREAMING... INT. MERCHANT’S APARTMENT, BEDROOM NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and we TRACK OUT of the SCREAMING MOUTH of JOHN MERCHANT. It’s 4 a.m. and John blinks his nightmare away as his wif BOBBI, clicks on a bedside light to reveal a modern-day apartment bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI
dialogues.text: Honey? You okay? Another dream?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Another dream. Or the same one.  Bobbi is an attractive mid-20’s woman. John is... very familiar looking. In fact, apart from the 20° century hai he’s a dead ringer for Phillip Lemarchand. Suddenly, the sound of more screams. Not John this time.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh shit. I woke Jack. Again. Bobbi’s already out of bed. John gets up and follows her through to... INT. MERCHANT’S APARTMENT, JACK’S ROOM (CONT. )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the bedroom of JACK, their seven-year-old, who, woken and disturbed by his father’s screams, is sitting on his bed. Bobbi and John rush over to him, Bobbi comforting him wit embrace while John looks apologetically distressed.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI
dialogues.text: There, there, sweetie. It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, partner. Don’t be scared. Just Daddy having ba dreams again.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI
dialogues.text: And dreams can’t hurt you, darling.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: They can’t hurt anybody. Bobbi has got Jack back beneath the covers. He’s already sleepy again but he looks up at his father

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Not even you, daddy?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No. No, not even me. Jack’s eyes close as Bobbi strokes his brow. He seems comforted by his father’s assurance but, as Bobbi and Joh find each other’s worried eyes, we see that they are less than their words imply.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHATEAU DU REVE DAY
dialogues.text: The Chateau looks identical to when we last saw it - exce that it now stands in 20th Century surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ante-room is now decorated as a modern-day living ro Jacques and Angelique are there. Angelique watches in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Do you know what I loathe about you most?

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: (between mouthfuls) “Do you know what I loathe about you most, master?”

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Master. It’s your lack of ambition. Have you sought power Influence? Fame? No. You... Jacques has a last swallow, belches, and interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES
dialogues.text: (putting a cigarette in his mouth) Light me. Another wave. The cigarette tip glows magically into life Jacques takes a deep satisfying drag and looks at her

dialogues.speaker: JACQUES

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI
dialogues.text: You look terrible.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (smiling) Love you, too.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI
dialogues.text: I’m worried. You should see someone.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You know I’ve had them all my life.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI
dialogues.text: As often? As bad? (John shakes his head) It’s your goddam grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: She was a wonderful woman.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI
dialogues.text: She was a weird woman. All those stories. How important y family is. How important you are. She put stuff in your m John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Not all of it. There’s stuff there that feels like... memories. Impossible memories. And they don’t just haunt dreams. They haunt my work. Everything I’ve done... He trails off, as if it’s impossible to explain.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI
dialogues.text: I don’t want you haunted. I don’t want you hurt.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: It’s not that. It’s stress. This Award Banquet tonight. I shit like that.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI
dialogues.text: Right. That’s why of all the buildings in the country, yo was voted the best. Bobbi picks up a magazine from the table and throws it to

dialogues.text: Hey, I didn’t say I wasn’t better than everyone else. I j said I could be better. I could’ve made it perfect. CLOSE on John as he picks up the magazine and we CUT TO..

dialogues.text: . A PASSENGER SHUTTLE suddenly hurtles toward us through dark and silent void. As it fills the frame, CUT TO REVER - and the shuttle speeds away from us, disappearing into distant darkness. Over its movement, a Super-imposed TITL

dialogues.text: Fires burn unchecked in the forests of Luna One tonight, roaring wildly beneath the great meta-glass canopies of t Pan-Pacific colony. Angry voices are being raised in Tokyo - particularly because Colonists could be transported to th Minos space station if that trillion-dollar facility was year behind schedule and, according to unconfirmed source not only out of radio-contact but also out of its geo- stationary orbit. (etc etc) At this point, the TV clicks off and the camera finds DR MERCHANT, sitting in a Rocco-style chair Paul is identical to Phillip and John except for a mole o cheek and his hair-colour. His face is haunted and obsess The single-minded genius of his ancestors has reached a neurotic fruition in him. Behind him, we see on a wall the 2204 ad equivalent of a board - a screen on which IMAGES replay in rotational dis The images are all familiar to us and all connected with bloodline’s history; The Box, the Cat’s-cradle design, fa portraits (photos of John, oils of Phillip, etc), sketche demons (Pinhead and Angelique), The Building, etc etc. Paul is addressing an unseen listener

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The distance from all inhabitated planets and colonies is important. It’s unclear what effect on the space-time continuum such a surge of metaphysical energy will have. There’s something strange about his voice. A little un-hu A little computer-generated. WIDEN TO REVEAL sitting opposite him, his hand at a comp console on his lap, DR PAUL MERCHANT! !

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (THE REAL ONE)
dialogues.text: I have to assume we’re far enough out now. Time has becom factor. He hits a key on his console and the first Paul BLINKS OU existence. He was a holographic Computer Program. Paul stands and crosses the room and we CHANGE ANGLRE to see... that the other end of the room is very different. The first part we saw was Paul’s living quarters. This part l like a control booth or a mixing bay. On a desk are three century MONITORS and a pair of latex gloves, each fingert connected by micro-filaments to a console beneath one of monitors. Below the desk and the monitors is a STAIRCASE leading do a separate structure - a large and massively solid HOLDIN PEN. It has a REINFORCED STEEL DOOR with a large locking mechanism. Paul sits at the desk and (as if movement-sensitive) one the monitors winks into life, and we CUT TO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a wall-mounted closed-circuit camera. A red light clicks on to establish its link with the monitor Paul is working The closed-circuit camera moves as if selecting an image We PULL AWAY to take in the room. It is a large bare spac the walls massively thick and very tall. It is some kind holding pen for something very dangerous. Currently, it’s empty except for a shadowed figure cross-legged in a corn There’s something familiar about this image. It’s a postu recognise. It reminds us of Elliot Spenser in HELLBOUND. It is a simple SERVO-ROBOT - a steel skeleton with fully articulated limbs. Its hands are close together in front its chest. And it’s holding the Lament Configuration. INT. PAUL’S CABIN/HOLDING PEN ANNEXE, MINOS (CONT. )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the monitor, we see the same image of the robot and th Box. Paul reaches over to the gloves... and a second monitor SQUAWKS into life, startling us.  On the monitor, CORRINNE COTTON, mid-20’s and attractive though her onepiece worksuit and business-like haircut do their best to ignore this. She’s the administrator of the Minos.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: (on monitor) Paul? Paul! I’m tracking a shuttle. It has to be governme They’re coming. I’m serious. A grimace of angry frustration crosses Paul’s face.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Corinne, I can’t be interrupted! Not now. I’m serious.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: Well, whatever it is you’re doing, Paul, you better do it fast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corrinne, too, is at a desk, working in front of a batch monitors. Six of them show EXTERIOR SHOTS of HUGE FLAT PA all decorated with Box-like patterns and all studded with (unlit) LIGHTS and MIRRORS. One monitor shows text: complicated co-ordinates for the alignment of the satelli

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (on monitor) You too. How’s it coming?

dialogues.speaker: CORRINNE
dialogues.text: Slowly. You sure I can’t suit-up and nudge these mothers hand?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You’ve got a good eye, Corrinne, but the alignment’s too precise. Trust the computers. Just keep feeding in the co ordinates. We’re so close. We’ve got to do it.

dialogues.speaker: CORRINNE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. PAUL’S CABIN/HOLDING PEN ANNEXE, MINOS (CONT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul breaks the video-link. He looks to the third monitor the screen comes a high-definition image of the Lament Configuration. It changes to a skeletal 3-D rendering of Box and moves around, showing it from al angles. The othe monitor still shows the robot and the Box. Breathing nervously, Paul squeezes his hands into the lat sensor-gloves. Watching both the 3-D graphic and the image from within pen, Paul moves his hands in front of him. He’s not actua holding anything but the movements of his hands look fami On the micro-glass monitor, the image of the Box moves an changes as if Paul were actually moving a real Box. We register the micro-filaments going into the console fr the gloves before we CUT TO...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: similar micro-filaments emerging from the wall behind the cross-legged robot and entering it at the elbows. The skeletal steel hands of the robot begin to move. With remote-controlled precision, its metal fingers play over Box, finding its secrets, discovering its hidden alignmen moving it closer and closer towards its final configurati and the Box jumps from the robot’s grip to land on the floor in front of it, where it makes its own final adjust A beat of silence and stillness... And the robot suddenly EXPLODES! In a jolting shock-momen is blasted apart, shattered to tiny fragments!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The passenger shuttle Endeavour speeds through space... and the camera SIFTS ANGLE to REVEAL where it’s heading..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Minos. In orbit around it are the SX SATELLITES, surrounding it in a way reminiscent of how the six faces the Box were laid out by Lemarchand on the edge of his ca cradle design. INT. PAUL’S CABIN, HOLDING PEN ANNWXE, MINOS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corrinne enters the annex. Paul is at the desk, his back her. He’s slumped back in his chair

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: Paul - I can’t do it. It’s your program. It needs you. (n reply) Paul? Paul, are you okay? She moves round to him. Paul looks like he’s in shock. He doesn’t even look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’s happened? Suddenly - a MASSIVE BANGING beyond the steel-reinforced like something huge and angry is trying to get out! Corinne starts in frightened shock

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: My God, Paul! What’s happened?!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: They’re here. A whole lifetime - many lifetimes - to get ready... But the sight of them...

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: Sight of who? Who’s here? Paul looks to the Pen-monitor. It clicks into life... ... and the snarling, terrifying face of the Chatter-Beas fills the screen, accompanied by its heart-stopping ROAR!

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: God in heaven, Paul; What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pen is transformed into a vision of Hell. A cold blue place of deep shadow and terror. The Chatter-Beast is not alone. Two other CENOBITES prowl shadows. We can’t yet see them clearly. An ARCHWAY OF BLUE LIGHT seems to form on the far wall of Pen. The Cenobites cease their prowling and watch... as Pinhead makes his entrance. Pinhead stalks elegantly into the centre of the Pen. He glances round, registers the shattered robot, the Box, an then his eyes go unerringly to the wall-mounted camera... INT. PAUL’S CABIN/HOLDING PEN ANNEXE, MINOS - THAT MOMENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and he addresses Paul directly through the monitor screen

dialogues.speaker: PINHEAD
dialogues.text: (on monitor) Merchant. I know you’re watching. We’d almost given up wa for you to play. Corinne’s face is an ashen mask of horror

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It knows you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We’ve never met. But he’s an old friend of the family. Paul clicks the monitor off. He turns to Corinne.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: There it is, Corinne. The hidden agenda you kept wonderin about.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: Never mind that. Can they get out?!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Two-foot thick concrete and steel. (beat) And I don’t kno hope not. A beat as they stare at each other

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I know you need a full explanation - But I have to go and those alignments before the shuttle gets here.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: Paul, the shuttle’s here.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Buy me time.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: The government pays my wages, Paul. I have to hand the st over. I...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s a question of minutes. Vital minutes. He stares at her, imploring. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: I’1l do what I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An entry-bay door opens on one of the stone towers rising the surface of the Minos and the Endeavour enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An airlock door opens... and we TRACK in suddenly to the FIGURES that come rushing into the entry bay. Four of the MILITARY - uniformed, armed, and masked. The other two ar civilians. EDWARDS, bureaucratic and embittered, is a male governme administrator. The other civilian is CHAMBERLAIN, a young looking scientist. The military is headed by CARDUCCI, a wiry and grizzled n bullshit professional. His tough-looking squad are RSCOE powerful very tall female), RIMMER (female), and PARKER (male). Edwards, Chamberlain, Carducci and the soldiers (arms at ready, scanning the area) walk into the large arrivals ar Hewn with rock, it’s as much a cavern as it is a room. (NB: PRODUCTION NOTE: This area and all the areas (mainly corridors) that are not function-specific have a half-fin laser-blasted look to them. There are grooves in the wall the rock where corridors and walkways were blasted throug Unless specifically described otherwise, everywhere on th Minos is rock, not steel or wood or plaster.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them look round at the laser-hewn space.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: CARDUCCI
dialogues.text: How the hell do they do this?

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: It’s pretty straightforward. Tractor-beams capture a suit small asteroid and then Meta-Lasers form the structures f the rock itself. It’s actually cheaper than building from scratch.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Cheaper until some crazy SOB takes it on an unscheduled t Stacked everywhere are crates and unopened boxes. Chamber reads the stencil-stamp on a crate.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: WZ-474's? They should have been wired in months ago. All stuff... (glancing round) He’s done nothing he’s supposed

dialogues.speaker: EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Then what has he been doing?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: (looking at the dank rock) Letting this place go to hell. A door opens and Corinne walks over to them. She takes in military and then addresses Edwards.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: Soldiers? Were you expecting armed resistance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady, when you maintain radio silence for a full six mont don’t know what to expect.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: I’m sure we can clear up any misunderstandings. I’m Corin Cotton, Administrator of the Minos.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Former administrator of the Minos. I’m Edwards, your successor. Corrinne opens her mouth to speak. Edwards raises a perem hand to silence her.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Here’s what I know. The Minos is Merchant’s baby. Six mon ago, he was ordered to hand it back to the government. He the whole crew home except for you and him. And then he t the whole goddam station out of orbit and headed into dee space. We’re taking it back and we’re installing Dr Chamberlain here as his replacement. It’s going to be cal It’s going to be cool. It’s going to be clean. (beat. To Carducci) Fan ‘em out, Dooch. The Soldiers move out at a trot into the Station.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: Wait! This isn’t necessary. We...

dialogues.speaker: EDWARDS
dialogues.text: (interrupting) The only reason you’re not under arrest is because my bleeding-heart self doesn’t want to screw up your pension From this moment until you’re back on Earth, you do two things: answer my questions and follow my orders. Got it? Corinne nods, staring distressed at the disappearing sold

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, hunched over the console, punches in co-ordinates a watches the minute movements of the satellites on the monitors. Two or three of the monitors show a graphic OVE with the word LOCKED flashing. Paul’s still working on th others. Suddenly, there’s a CREAK behind him. Paul spins round... to find himself staring directly into a gun-barrel! Roscoe’s holding the gun.

dialogues.speaker: ROSCOE
dialogues.text: Dr Merchant? Consider yourself relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rimmer and Parker walk along an opressive, dimly-lit corr They reach the door to Paul’s cabinand the Holding Pen An Rimmer tries the handle. Locked. She looks questioningly Parker. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Investigate all areas. That’s what they said. Rimmer leans back and delivers a shoulder-slam to the doo opens.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: So let’s investigate. She leads the way in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul’s face stares out from behind bars at Edwards and Carducci.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You don’t know what you’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Actually, we do. We’re keeping you out of the goddam way we find out what the hell you’ve been doing here.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No! You don’t understand! It’s dangerous!

dialogues.speaker: CARDUCCI
dialogues.text: Dangerous how? Paul looks from one to the other. Can he tell them? Would believe him? He has to chance it

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: There are demons on the ship. Carducci bursts into LAUGHTER.

dialogues.speaker: CARDUCCI
dialogues.text: (to Edwards) Well, that solves that mystery. What went wrong on the Mi Dr Merchant went out of his fucking mind. INT. PAUL’S CABIN/HOLDING PEN ANNEXE, MINOS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parker and Rimmer make their way down through the cabin t annexe. Parker gestures to the pen-monitor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’s this hooked up to? Rimmer looks down the stairway to the reinforced door, th back at the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Whatever’s in there, I guess. The monitor, sensing movement, clicks on. While Rimmer ma her way down the staircase, Parker looks at the monitor. image it shows is of the completely empty holding pen. Th BLUE LIGHT pulses briefly over the screen. Parker’s eyes on the screen. Another BLUE PULSE. And another. His eyes and focus... and suddenly his face moves into horrified r ON THE MONITOT: The holding pen is full of CHILDREN, frightened, hungry, and chained to the walls!

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: My God! Fuelled by outrage, he hurtles down the stairs, levelling weapon at the reinforced door BLASTS of ENERGY smash into the huge door and BLOW IT APA Rimmer, much nearer the door and nearly caught in the bla throws herself aside.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: Parker, what the fuck are you doing?! Parker rushes past her through the smoking ruin of the do INT. HOLDING PEN, MINOS CONT. ... and into the holding pen. At first, al he can see is shadows and light.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Where are the children? Rimmer appears in the wrecked doorway.

dialogues.speaker: RIMMER
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Parker suddenly points to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: What the hell’s this? Both register the SHATTERED METAL FRAGMENTS of the robot littering the floor around the Box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (of f ) The remnants of a most unsatisfying victim. Parker and Rimmer start in shock as Pinhead emerges from shadows. Movements from all around add to the terror as t other Cenobites shuffle in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER/RIMMER
dialogues.text: (simultaneous/ad-1ib) Oh my God... What the fuck... Sweet suffering Christ... (

dialogues.speaker: PINHEAD
dialogues.text: Still - you’re here to change all that, aren’t you? A brief, imperious gesture of the demon’s head... and a METALLIC FRAGMENT, jaggedly pointed like a badly- made Shuriken, suddenly rises up from the wrecked robot spinning fast and furiously as if by magic... and then HURTLES ACROSS THE ROOM! Before he can even react, it slams into Parker - SLICING HIS FACE OFF!! He falls to the ground... and Rimmer has the sense to turn tail and run... ... but she trips on the jagged edge of the blasted door falls to the ground. She swings herself round and half-si - just in time to see the Chatter-Beast launch itself fro darkness and land on her, its terrible jaws slashing, snapping, and slavering!

dialogues.speaker: TIME-CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. PAUL’S CABIN/HOLDING PEN ANNEXE, MINOS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in the living quarters end of Paul’s cabin. And so Pinhead, the Beast and the Cenobites. This is our first clear look at the other two Cenobites: is brand-new, A SIAMESE-TWIN CENOBITE joined at the side the head and at the lower chest and the hips. The other is Angelique. Though her face and figure are st beautiful, she has been “Cenobitised”: Like all Cenobites is bald and blue-skinned and her individuality has given to the leather-and-mutilation uniform of Pinhead’s troops She looks at the living quarters, at Paul’s deliberate 18 century look. We see her recognise the style - and the bloodline’s taste.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Toymaker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time for games. Merchant has a plan. He mustn’t exerci it. Kill them all. Pinhead, the Beast, and the Siamese-Twin move out through room to the corridor. Angelique lingers a moment, taking these reminders of her past - the furnishings, the pictur the automata. Her hands trail over an object or two, her beneath their Cenobite coldness, helplessly nostalgic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwards and Carducci are talking while Paul observes them behind bars.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARDS
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CARDUCCI
dialogues.text: How much clearer can I be? Parker and Rimmer haven’t radi in. They’re missing. Paul closes his eyes in dread.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Where did you send them? They ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARDS
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (louder ) Where did you send them?!

dialogues.speaker: EDWARDS
dialogues.text: Quiet!

dialogues.speaker: CARDUCCI
dialogues.text: (to Paul) Your work-area.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: They’re dead. And if you don’t let me out to finish my wo we’re all dead. Carducci looks to Edwards. He nods back to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: CARDUCCI
dialogues.text: That’s your call. I’m going to notify Roscoe and Chamberl to proceed with caution. Carducci exits. Edwards crosses to talk to Paul directly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever’s going on - if anything’s going on - how the he I know you’re not responsible? Paul sighs. Frustrated. And guilty. He is responsible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roscoe patrols a low-level service corridor. Dank rock. W floor. Dismal lighting. It’s a creepy atmosphere. Shadows us. We keep waiting for something to leap out at Roscoe.. nothing does. Yet. Ahead of her is an entrance door. Hefting her weapon, she in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : and enters the Flight Deck. This is more brightly-lit t the corridor but its emptiness is still creepy. Roscoe is much on guard and walks through cautiously, rifle cocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the room where Corinne and Paul worked on the satellite alignments. We now see more of the room. It’s t electronic heart of the Minos - a large space full of hum data banks and pulsing generators. Wires, conduits, and f optic cables run everywhere from machine to machine. Chamberlain is at a large Systems-Analysis Monitor, on wh blueprint-like diagrams of the Minos flash across the scr

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: (to himself) He’s done nothing. Nothing... In the distance beyond him, unseen by him, a FIGURE moves eerily between the “doorway formed by two generators! Chamberlain keeps scrolling through the data base.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: And what the hell are these satellites? Suddenly, a SOUND from somewhere behind him. Chamberlain in shock and swings round.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Hello? Nothing. Cocking his head, Chamberlain moves out into the room. He begins to walk through the machinery. Because of stacking and positioning of the banks and the generators, place has a maze-like feel of many intersecting small walkways.  Chamberlain makes his way down the walkways. An eerie atmosphere descends. There are SOUNDS and FLEETING SHADOW everywhere in this place. Is something in here with him? begins to look over his shoulder often. His tread becomes quiet and cautious. He turns a corner. At the end of the walkway, a vaguely h shaped shadow. Very slowly, he moves toward it... to find nothing but a pile of boxes, stacked unevenly in such a way that they cast a misleading shadow. Chamberlain exhales in relief.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Shit... He turns back into the walkway he left - and is suddenly to faces with the Siamese-Twin, Cenobite!

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: What the... ?! The creature suddenly and instantly SPLITS IN Two, its tw selves springing apart and one of them sweeping past Chamberlain! Chamberlain stands between the Twins, terror on his face. The Twins speak, alternating words as if they are still o

dialogues.speaker: TWIN 1/TWIN 2
dialogues.text: I cannot bear to be apart from my brother They raise their arms and walk toward each other... and RE-MERGE, their flesh stretching eagerly toward each other’s, crushing and assimilating the SCREAMING Chamberl between themselves/itself! The Twins are Siamese again. There’s nothing left of Chamberlain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corinne stands as close to Paul as the bars allow. Edward some distance away.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s what my family has lived for for two centuries. It’s destiny. My duty. To free the world from the demons my bloodline unleashed.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: By building a space station?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By building a trap. And destroying them forever. But the satellites aren’t ready. The Elysium Configuration can’t triggered. What I built as a trap has become a nest.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me sooner?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Like I didn’t seem crazy enough? Nobody need ever have kn This was meant to be a one-man operation once everything ready. Now people are dying. I wish you hadn’t stayed.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: I wanted to stay. Paul looks at Corinne as if that had never occurred to hi Her eyes are saying something they’ve probably been sayin months but he was too driven to notice. She likes him. A

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You’ve got to get off now. Get to a shuttle. Corinne shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: CORINNE
dialogues.text: Wwe’ve got to get you out of here. INT. PAUL’S CABIN/HOLDING-PEN ANNEXE, MINOS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carducci is at the bottom of the staircase, staring in ho at what’s left of Parker and Rimmer. He flicks open a tiny intercom.

dialogues.speaker: CARDUCCI
dialogues.text: Roscoe? Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: ROSCOE
dialogues.text: (on intercom) Flight deck.

dialogues.speaker: CARDUCCI
dialogues.text: Can’t raise Chamberlain. Don’t know what the fuck’s going But shoot first. You copy?

dialogues.speaker: ROSCOE
dialogues.text: Check. Carducci pockets the intercom and makes his way up the st

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The living quarters part of the room. We hear the sound Carducci climbing the stairs - as does the Angelique Ceno who is still in the room. She crosses to closet. Its door is a full-length mirror. swings it open. The inside door is also fully-mirrored. S pauses for a moment to look at her reflection on the inne door. The reflection is of her former-self, in all its human be The Angelique Cenobite STEPS THROUGH THE MIRROR - coming the other side as her “human” self! ANGLE ON Carducci as he reaches the top of the stairs and moves into the cabin... to see Angelique sitting on the bed, a look of terror on her face.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: Help me. Please help me... Carducci scans the room quickly, on guard.

dialogues.speaker: CARDUCCI
dialogues.text: What’s happened? Are they here? Angelique stands up. Carducci crosses to her. Doing a per imitation of a pre-feminist damsel-in-distress, Angelique throws her arms round this big strong man and presses her helpless self to him for protection. They are standing in front of the still-open mirror-door.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELIQUE
dialogues.text: No. Not now. But they’re everywhere. I’m so afraid... Carducci can’t help it. He’s a professional. But there’s beautiful woman pressing herself to him. He relaxes his b and puts his arms round her...

dialogues.speaker: CARDUCCI
